body: An exceptionally violent Monday night and Tuesday in the city added seven names to the list of those killed in 2003, now at 594 and uncomfortably close to the 600 mark hailed for the last year as a sign of a safer New York. In addition, two people died in a fire in the Bronx that appears to have been set, the police said. Those deaths have not been
title: Homicides Surge in City as Year Nears End

body: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) title: Solemnizing the Holidays With a Cornucopia of Music

body: LIKE a lot of residents of a little corner of Flatbush, Brooklyn, known as Ditmas Park and Ditmas Park West, Katleen Felix Ranger and her husband, Pascal, a cosmetics executive, started their housing search in fashionable Park Slope. title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Ditmas Park and Ditmas Park West; Spirited Enclaves With Grand Homes

body: An article yesterday about the police investigation into the killing of a Fairfield University student in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood where his body was found. It was Prospect Park South, not Ditmas Park.
title: Corrections

body: A little more than two hours before he was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street early Sunday morning, a Fairfield University student withdrew $20 from an automated teller machine in a delicatessen three blocks from the place where his body was found, the authorities said yesterday. The receipt for the 4:23 a.m. withdrawal at the 11-Seven Food Shop,
title: Retracing Steps Of a Student In the Hours Before He Died

body: If you happen to attend public school in Brooklyn or Queens, chances are you are sleeping late and may never glimpse this article because today is all about leisure. If you are stuck in Manhattan, the Bronx or Staten Island, on the other hand, suck it up and get to class. Such are the vagaries of Brooklyn-Queens Day, a relic of a school holiday
title: School's Out? Here's a History Lesson About Brooklyn-Queens Day

body: IN the history of New York, certain businesses have behaved like the tide, rising when conditions are right, receding when the city outgrows them. Horse stables, which once flourished in Manhattan, are now reduced to a handful. Vaudeville theaters died away after the movies moved in. Now, indoor tennis faces a similar fate. Two clubs in Long Island
title: URBAN TACTICS; Where Late the Sweet Rackets Twanged
